newsitem.title: UK: Dog owners compete to show the perfect best friend.
newsitem.headline: Dog owners compete to show the perfect best friend.

text.p: Thousands of dogs and their owners will compete this week for the title of "best at show" at Crufts, the self-proclaimed "greatest dog show in the world".
More than 15,000 exhibitors and 100,000 visitors will gather at Britain's National Exhibition Centre on Thursday for the start of the four-day event.
To a dog-owner, winning Crufts is the ultimate accolade.
"It was a dream come true," said Patricia Bentley who last year won with her three-year old Cocker Spaniel, Albert.
"I was delighted, it's something you only do once in a lifetime," she told Reuters. "It is the most prestigious dog show in the world and to win is every exhibitor's dream."
Crufts is the World Cup, or Wimbledon championship, of the dog world, according to Brian Leonard, external affairs executive of the Kennel Club, which organises the show.
"It's synonymous with quality. Whenever you get a cat show, or a parrot or pigeon show, it's always billed as the Crufts of the pigeon world' or whatever," he said.

The competing dogs are divided into six groups: hounds, gun-dogs, terriers, utility (large companion dogs such as poodles and Dalmatians), working, and toys (such as Chihuahuas). The judges decide on a winner in each group and those six dogs go forward to compete for "best of show". The winner receives the Keddell Memorial Trophy, a huge silver cup named after Robert Keddell, the show's manager from 1894 to 1924.
The competing dogs are whittled down by expert judges who look at their physique, temperament and handling until the best shines out.
The winning dog is easy to spot in the final contest, said Leonard.
"You can tell the winning dog by the reaction of the crowd when the handler walks it into the ring. They just sit back and there is this "aaah" around the ring," he explained.
Crufts is a very British affair. Although the show boasts worldwide media coverage, British quarantine laws make it difficult for foreign dog-owners to enter their thoroughbreds.
Some British dog owners have become a little too eager to win at shows.

At a recent Northern Counties show one exhibitor secretly administered a sedative to a competitor's Chihuahua. At an Open Retriever stake held at Sandringham, the Queen's country home, another exhibitor was alleged to have mistreated her labrador.

Such behaviour was "totally unacceptable", said Leonard, adding that the Kennel Club uses its disciplinary powers to ban any owners who resort to skulduggery, mistreat their dogs, or behave disrespectfully towards judges.
"The dog has to be enjoying itself or else it will not show well," he said. "The handler too has to be very relaxed. Any nerves will be transferred down the lead. It's a very close relationship."
So, after the recent success in cloning a sheep in Scotland, would the Kennel Club want to clone a Crufts winner?
"No," said Leonard. "What we're trying to do is breed better dogs and not to simply reproduce what we have already achieved."
What about cloning a winning Crufts handler?
"Hopefully we're improving them all the time too by better training. But a certain amount of it comes from breeding," Leonard said with a laugh.
